[[Providence, Rhode Island]] Edward Mitchell Bannister(ca. 1828 January 9, 1901) was aBlack Canadian-United StatesAmericantonalismTonalistPaintingpainter. Like other Tonalists, his style and predominantly pastoral subject matter were drawn from his admiration forJean-Franois MilletMilletand the FrenchBarbizon School.
article.heading: Biography
article.paragraph: File:Edward Mitchell Bannister - Landscape - Google Art Project.jpgthumbLandscapeBannister was born inSt. Andrews, New Brunswickand moved toNew Englandin the late 1840s, where he remained for the rest of his life. While Bannister was well known in the artistic community of his adopted home ofProvidence, Rhode Islandand admired within the wider East Coast art world (he won a bronze medal for his large oil "Under the Oaks" at the 1876Centennial ExpositionPhiladelphia Centennial), he was largely forgotten for almost a century for a complexity of reasons, principally connected with racial prejudice.

With the ascendency of theAfrican-American Civil Rights Movement (1955-1968)Civil Rights movementin the 1970s, his work was again celebrated and collected. In 1978,Rhode Island Collegededicated its Art Gallery in Bannister's name with the exhibition: "Four From Providence ~ Alston, Bannister, Jennings & Prophet". This event was attended and commented on by numerous notable political figures of the time, and supported by the Rhode Island Committee for Humanities and the Rhode Island Historical Society. Events like this, across the entire cultural landscape, have ensured that his artwork and life will not be again forgotten.

Although primarily known for his idealisedLandscape artlandscapesand seascapes, Bannister also executedportraits, biblical and mythological scenes, andGenre worksgenrescenes. An intellectualautodidacticismautodidact, his tastes in literature were typical of an educatedVictorian eraVictorianpainter, includingEdmund SpenserSpenser,Virgil,John RuskinRuskinandAlfred Tennyson, 1st Baron TennysonTennyson, from whose works much of his iconography can be traced.
Bannister died of a heart attack in 1901 while attending a prayer meeting at his church, Elmwood Avenue Free Baptist Church. He is buried in theNorth Burial Groundin Providence.
article.heading: Legacy
article.paragraph: The historian Anne Louise Avery is currently compiling the first Catalogue Raisonn and major biography of Bannister's work. See theInternational Foundation for Art Researchfor further details.
E. M. Bannister Gallery atRhode Island Collegeis named after Bannister.cite newshttp://www.ric.edu/bannister/about_emb.phpEdward Mitchell Bannister[[Rhode Island College]]2014-03-16
article.heading: House
article.paragraph: The house at 93 Benevolent Street in Providence, where Bannister lived between 1884 to 1899, is owned byBrown University.Brown plans to renovate the property and restore it to its original appearance.cite webCoelhoCourtneyBrown to renovate historic Bannister Househttps://news.brown.edu/articles/2015/05/bannisterNews from BrownBrown University15 May 201513 May 2015The house at 93 Benevolent Street, once home to African American artist Edward Mitchell Bannister and currently owned by Brown University, will be fully renovated, returned to its original wood exterior ...
